ca.mcgill.ecse211.project

Class Navigation

  • java.lang.Object
    • ca.mcgill.ecse211.project.Navigation
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.lang.Runnable

    public class Navigation
extends java.lang.Object
implements java.lang.Runnable
    This class is used to navigate the robot around the playing field

      • travelTo

        public static void travelTo(double x,
            double y)
        Travels to coordinates x and y. Calls turnTo to set the angle first then sets the motors to forward and rotates the distance required to get there.

        If isAvoiding is true (enabled), it will check if the Ultrasonic sensor distance is below a threshold. If it is, it means it has detected an obstacle and will run the avoid() method.

        It will also if its location is close to the launch point and when it is, it will sweep the sensor again to check if an obstacle is on that point. If there's an obstacle, it will get the next launch point and travel to that point

        Parameters:
        x - the x-coordinate of waypoint
        y - the y-coordinate of waypoint

      • turnTo

        public static void turnTo(double theta)
        This method makes the robot turn to an absolute theta using the minimal angle.
        Parameters:
        theta - the theta of the direction we want to face

      • turnTo

        public static void turnTo(double x,
          double y)
        turnTo method but with point input instead of angle
        Parameters:
        x - x-coordinate of travel point
        y - y-coordinate of travel point

      • convertDistance

        public static int convertDistance(double distance)
        Converts input distance to the total rotation of each wheel needed to cover that distance.
        Parameters:

        Returns:
        the wheel rotations necessary to cover the distance

      • convertAngle

        public static int convertAngle(double angle)
        Converts input angle to the total rotation of each wheel needed to rotate the robot by that angle.
        Parameters:

        Returns:
        the wheel rotations necessary to rotate the robot by the angle

      • computeTheta

        public static double computeTheta(double x,
                  double y)
        This method computes the absolute theta to where it needs to go by using the odometer for its initial position/theta and (x and y) for its displacement vector.
        Depending on where the vector is facing from the relative position of the robot, it will set the appropriate theta. The appropriate theta is calculated with the 0 degree facing North and increasing degrees turning clock-wise.
        Parameters:
        x - the target x-coordinate
        y - the target y-coordinate
        Returns:
        the absolute theta of the destination

      • travelTrajectory

        public static java.util.List<Resources.Point> travelTrajectory(Resources.Point start,
                                               Resources.Point end)
        For the calculateTrajectory function, there are two main cases, either we are on the on the lower or upper line of the rectangle, or on the left or right line of it.
        In each of these two cases, there are 3 separate cases, with 1, 2, or 3 coordinate points necessary to get to the end point.

        For the 1 coordinate point case, we tell the robot to go directly to the end point, since it is on the same line as the starting point.

        For the 2 coordinate point case, we tell the robot to first match either the X or Y coordinate to get on the same line as the end point, and then go to the end point itself.

        Finally, for the 3 coordinate point case, we first travel to one of the perpendicular lines, then travel along that line to get to the end line, and then we call travel to the end line itself.

        Parameters:
        start - start point
        end - end point
        Returns:
        Sequence of waypoints to follow to reach the end point

      • trajectoryDistance

        public static double trajectoryDistance(Resources.Point start,
                        java.util.List<Resources.Point> trajectory)
        The trajectoryDistance function is used to calculate a "cost" value for the robot to follow a specific trajectory.

        We input the start point, along with a trajectory from the calculateTrajectory function. It will iterate through all the points in the trajectory list of points, and compute the sum of all the euclidian distances from the start point and the trajectory points. When we compare all the distances for all the possible launch point trajectories, we can find the closest one to the robot and travel to that one.

        Parameters:
        start - start point
        trajectory - sequence of points to reach an end point
        Returns:
        "cost" or total distance to reach the end point using wall hugging travel

      • findLaunchPoints

        public static java.util.Collection<Resources.Point> findLaunchPoints()
        Calculates the launch to the corresponding bin point

        If we're using obstacle avoidance, this method creates multiple lines smaller than the island's width and height on the top right edges of the play area.
        We then create a circle with its center on the bin point with a radius of the robot's launch distance. The circumference of the circle is all the points that the robot can shoot from and the lines represent the permitted points that are not out of bounds. So, we simply get the intersection points from the circle and the lines (We imported a special Math.geom jar file to get the points). Then, we sort the list of intersection points by its closest distance to the robot's.

        If we're not using obstacle avoidance, it means we're using the wall hugging approach where we just travel on the edges to avoid obstacles.
        We simply create 4 lines that shapes the island area but slightly smaller since these lines represent where our robot can shoot from and we're only travelling on the edges. We do the same thing with the circle with the bin point and find the corresponding interesection points. The list of points is not sorted for this approach.

        Returns:
        a list of viable launch points (sorted if using obstacle avoidance)
